job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Ramon, CA
pros:
- amazing coworkers 
- a genuine mission that is to support people 
- decent benefits & merit increases
cons:
- management *not all*. Some managers could literally care less about the people they manage. Some are very delusional and can't even do half of the hard work themselves. Severe lack of self-awareness. The HR team is the best. 

- Communication. You will literally get a different set of directions and expectations depending on what manager you ask despite it being the same objective. It's laughable. 

- focus on numbers, not people. I don't know how many times this ridiculous CEO emphasizes the numbers. Its always, "the numbers... data... more data, oh, by the way, we have to look at the numbers". Trust your people to understand, empower your managers to explain what the numbers mean (clearly), and speak to what the numbers represent. They're literally peoples lives, not some metric to base our performance off of. Just be human and speak to that!

pros: Mission-focused company with great leadership.
cons: Need to enrich the work experience. Salary should catch up to the bay area's living conditions.

pros: The mission alone is enough. I actually worked at another OPO prior to transitioning to DNW. I have always been connected to the mission but was losing hope in Executive Leadership as I witnessed some very underhanded things happening at my former OPO. I find it strange and pretty ludicrous that I’ve read the CEO at DNW is not connected to the mission and only about numbers because it’s the complete opposite. The CEO is a passionate and compassionate woman who does place an emphasis on numbers in this organization to illustrate how it MATTERS for the number of lives that we SAVE. That’s our entire purpose for being here. The CEO has expectations of every single employee in this organization to do our part to carry out this mission. She is also the same person who takes the time to follow up with outcomes of people she has never met and gets excited to hear that they have been successfully transplanted and are doing well. There has been a lot of change. Most of it is due to former tenured or short term employees who exhibit a sense of entitlement and don’t meet expectations. So change is good. There is room for growth internally and it is supported by leadership. Frontline clinical staff have major flexibility being able to work from home and still meet their compensation demands EVEN if they don’t have to go out on cases. The learning and development department is building and in my opinion finally have the right people in leadership to improve and support our training and ongoing education efforts. Human Resources also finally has a true leader who is well versed in what she does and reliable. There is so much opportunity here. One just has to be connected to our true purpose and willing to actually do the work that is expected of them. There are additionally many benefits provided that most workplaces don’t have. Cell phone allowance, gym or exercise class allowance, and during the terrible hike in gas prices EVERY employee received a gas stipend. I’m not sure where you can find that elsewhere. Especially not in a place where you receive mileage reimbursement (which DNW also provides for some positions ) DEI is a priority as it should be and we have an awesome team of people who ensure we all have learning opportunities for this. I find so much value in this because I whole heartedly believe that some of the reviews of our CEO have a lot to do with the fact that she is a minority woman. It’s unfair!!
cons: We are a large and growing OPO who has been short staffed since the day I walked in. The positions are open and remain open because the Bay Area area is an expensive place to live. There needs to be some serious consideration to lobby the board for fair salaries that compete with other Bay Area healthcare facilities. Being short staffed leads to a spiral of things such as employee burn out, no time for training , poor retention and interruption to work life balance. There are some very negative entitled people who are complacent with getting a pay check and not doing the work to earn it. Those people need to be encouraged to move on to their happy place and gladly supported thru their transition because this work is not for everyone and that’s ok. Those who feel like the CEO is insensitive for mentioning the life span of a career in an OPO need to be further educated. This is not the first CEO to share this information. This is DATA from all OPO’s from some period or another. In fact clinical employee lifespan at some point in my career use to be 18 months. That’s was an average from all of the OPO’s not an insensitive comment from a single CEO .

review_title: Don’t be fooled by the infomercial; you won’t last 5 years according to the CEO.
job_title: Clinical Procurement Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: The in line staff are great. Helping families during their most difficult times of their lives is a great altruistic thing to do.
cons: This organization went from employee focused to CEO and upper management focused. They talk about numbers being a person that is saved. Turn over is a ongoing issue. Great companies expect to retain their employees; this CEO has normalized turnover and doesn’t care if you are burned out. If you are registered as an organ donor they will dictate the process. This will no longer be a family driven process and it takes away from the family. Weekends are rotated and holidays are selected yearly based on seniority. So don’t count on Christmas or Thanksgiving off. The organization has placed its money on traveling staff instead of supporting it’s full time employees. Family department is treated as if they have to perform as a sales person selling cars. Their performance is graded based on getting families to say yes to organ or tissue donation. If they do not get authorizations they are demoted and placed on remedial plans with potential of losing their jobs. So if you sign up to be an organ donor your family will not have a say about the timing or process. This organization will not walk away from your loved one until they make sure to get every organ; even if they end up discarding the organs because they were not suitable. It is no longer family driven or family centered. Every organ every time is the modo.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Ramon, CA
pros: I have worked in several health care venues and I have never experienced such a phenomenal place to work. Led by the CEO, VP's and Directors of DNWest we are saving lives everyday! The CEO is dedicated to the mission of helping people receive life saving organs and changing the future for so many. There are many unfair opinions on this site and certainly do not reflect the true experience of working at DNWest. RUN to this organization! If you want to trust those in leadership and have meaning in your work this is the best place. No better place to work than DNWest
cons: There is an emotional cost associated with working with death and dying. One must focus on the fact that death for everyone is inevitable, but helping grieving families find meaning in their loss by saving another human beings life is rewarding. Self care is a must.

review_title: Don't, If you can help it
pros: Not too many pros unfortunately.
cons: Bad management from the top down, company does not support or back the technicians. Anyone who doesn't work in the office is second class and is not made a priority. Slow response times, useless meetings that could be summarized in an email. Poor bonus and raise pay, does not meet inflation rate. Quarterly rating system is unfair and not judged correctly, very little room for improvement from management

job_title: Donation Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: Positive contribution to society. Nice building.
cons: Bad management and incompetent leaders. While this is a fact, I'd like to note there are a few really great leaders but unfortunately the bad outweigh the good. The company has a bad habit of hiring individuals out of desperation, so you end up with leaders that do not know know how to lead, show little interest in actually learning the job, and eventually end up quitting. Additionally, most of the leaders lack interpersonal communication skills. The just simply don't know how to interact with employees and lack conflict resolution skills. The turn over is incredibly high. With so much turn over, there's just no continuity and it feels like you're starting all over with new protocols and ideas ever few months. The morale is incredibly low and few work as a team. With the current culture of the company, I would not recommend anyone to work there until there is a major change. They have a lot of work to do. As a whole, the mission is beautiful, they just needs to get the right people running things.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Ramon, CA
pros: As a leader in the organization I feel supported. It has only been a short tenure with the organization but my professional growth has been supported. The CEO is passionate about the mission. She is tied to the customers we serve as if they were her own family. I have worked for her before under different titles in leadership but knew when this opportunity was presented I would accept. I had no doubts about accepting this opportunity because I am a true believer in "starting at the top". I knew that her passion for the mission would trickle down into every single department and person employed with the organization. Thru much change and re-alignment I still feel the mission is effectively being carried out and most staff is open to change. I was employed in another OPO for 10 years and I considered that organization home. I acquired a great work family there so moving on to DNW was a huge decision for me. Overall it has been well worth it. Being able to be a part of this mission will always be a privilege to me but I feel even more privileged to be able to work under this CEO's leadership.
cons: There are a few individuals in the organization who have long tenure and are not open to change.

review_title: I work with some of the best clinicians and Family coordinators, but we have a horrible CEO
job_title: Clinical Procurement Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros:
-Some of the best people I have ever worked with, 
- The mission is something we all believe in
-Pay is on par with other OPOs
cons:
-Healthcare benefits are on par, but another option other than Kaiser and Sutter would be great. 
-Toxic leadership from CEO which borders on harassment
- Constant fear of being terminated, 

It's a job where we are all stewards of the gift the donors and their families gave, in which all of us work diligently to do the very best for the donor family. 

Unfourtunately, our current CEO's leadership ability is poor at best, and at worst is toxic. You will work your very hardest to make it all happen, but the minute you fail you will be told that because of you "recipients will die." 

I have never met the CEO, we have never had a CEO breakfast or lunch that the odd 5 star reviews have mentioned. The only time I have heard from the CEO is when she does something horrific, or when she writes a CEO corner. 

That said, if we had a different CEO I would rate this organization five stars, but because of our current CEO we have lost a ton of experienced clinical coordinators who were perhaps the best in the field because of her mismanagement.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Ramon, CA
pros: Really great, compassionate and enthusiastic colleagues on the ground with you. Pay is average for the area.
cons:
I’d been around for a long time through many iterations of change, and I must say, despite all of her initial process, the new CEO and all of her cronies she’s hired to fill top spots have driven DNW into the ground. 

Numbers are up and that is all that matters. This management team, CEO and every VP/director, doesn’t care about a single thing other than that. They don’t care home many burned bridges there are with hospitals, how many donor families are left devastated by their callousness, or how many good employees quit in the wake of their rampages. 

DNW used to be an enviable workplace, now it’s embarrassing to even have it on my resume.

job_title: Tissue Recovery Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: The recovery team is amazing. It's like working with family. The work is fascinating and rewarding.
cons:
- underpaid and discrepancies in pay
- they abuse your body. They say they won't give you a large donor without adequate staffing but that's only true depending on what upper management is around. Lot's of overuse/work injuries that they will push you out for
- management is a complete joke. They don't know anything about tissue recovery, so if you ever have a question you'll get misleading and false information. Supervisors are never in the office and no one knows how to find them. They live a cushy salary job with zero accountability and take all the credit for all the work the techs are doing. 
- sexist and inappropriate: one supervisor loves making comments about women and stereotyping them; the other makes sexual comments about what she does with her boyfriend. Don't bother going to HR; they will ask you for documentation of the event which obviously you don't have and then let them continue their egregious habits.
-don't get injured! you will be pushed out. 
- they sow psychological and emotional trauma
- no ability to advance in the company. It's all nepotism.

pros:
Old school moved into the 21 century.
Work that is important and meaningful.
Pay is "ok"
Benefits are inflated, but good.
cons:
Management lies (but most likely that's everywhere)
If you are in the "click" and ride the coattails of others you will go far while qualified people are overlooked.
Claims transparency, but we all know that's far from the truth.
Pays one group an obscene amounts of money to do nothing yet rides other groups that work hard to work harder.
In the end it's all about the money. Don't be fooled by the "non-profit" title that's held. Management lives for their big end of year bonus while others are handed a small token of a bonus.
Be sure to understand and know what it means to sign up on the registry, because your family will be forced to follow through even if you know for a fact the person changed their mind. 
Money, money, money money!

review_title: Mission driven organization with lots of amazing people
job_title: Donation Development in San Ramon, CA
pros: DNWest is a mission driven organization and the work is truly fulfilling no matter what role you're in. There has been significant change in the organization since I've worked here, especially with the new CEO on boarding last January. She is focused on employee retention and very passionate about our mission to save and heal lives. DNWest also offers good benefits including health, vision, dental, PTO, retirement, etc. The new Chief of HR (the VP of HR from an old review is gone!) is also committed to improving benefits and satisfaction of employees. It's encouraging to see the changes that have been made thus far and it's exciting to see the potential of this organization in the years to come.
cons: DNWest is adjusting their business practices and staffing to match their current workloads and growth. With growth comes the usual growing pains. Work/life balance and compensation can be a challenge with the high cost of living and long commute times, but that is the same for any Bay Area based non profit organization.

pros: Fantastic Mission.  The work is truly life giving and very gratifying.
cons: COO doesn't understand the meaning of teamwork.  He leads with a stick and is quick to judge.  He looks for fault rather than solutions. He plays favorites with some and targets others.  Decisions are made among two to three people at the top and decisions pushed down.  He does not allow for independent leader decision making.  Must be his way.  Blame culture is a huge problem.

review_title: Working for CTDN is the opportunity of a lifetime
pros:
Highly respected organization serving the needs of families and transplant centers related to organ donation. They are a premier resource for the community at large regarding organ and tissue donation.
Management is highly skilled and have woked diligently to create a positive, supportive environment.
Diversity is respected, creative initiative fostered and respect is present at all levels. Overtime is generously compensated.
cons: In many of the job catagories there is the possibility of needing to work overtime, although overtime is well compensated, the hours can be challenging. Travel occurs often and may involve fling in a small plane with a single pilot.

review_title: Started out as an amazing job with purpose and flexibility... All that has gone by the way side.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Leandro, CA
pros: Purposeful work. What you do each day makes a difference in people's lives... Literally.
cons: Management. Pay. Constant understaffing. Constant directional change. Do more with less attitude about everything. Micromanagement.

review_title: Great mission statement still going through a lot of change
pros: Great mission statement, good benefits, reimbursed timely, support staff (admin) available as much as possible even in a 24/7 work environment. Provides leadership classes for all levels of management. All staff meetings worth going to.
cons: The company has been going through changes for the past 5 years. It is difficult to get things done when senior leadership is not on the same page, however in the last 6 months, things are getting done in a more timely manner

review_title: Overall rating of the organization is a 5, but I hate to say only a 2 for the Operations Call-Center
job_title: Donation Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: The company is in the middle of going through some big changes.  The "NEW" CEO is strong and she has the right vision for this company and it fantastic mission.  The New Management is impressive.  The Director of Operations, The VP of Operations, Human Resources, Education and IT practice the AIDET Plus the Promise.  The Mission of this organization is the "GOLD STANDARD" of missions and the new CEO wants to make this OPO Gold Standard.  I believe she will.  I witnessed her poise, composure and grace under pressure.
cons: The Supervisors in the Department are under a lot of stress and managing an understaffed department.  So their patience is short.   My time at the organization was short, 6 days in training, two were general Company On-Boarding, two were general overview of Organ and Tissue Donation.   Half a with an educator on the actual position, and two days for online LMS training, reviewing Harassment, Corporate Compliance and Safety.   Then general knowledge of Policies and Procedures.  I listened in on a total of maybe 6 calls and the Supervisors were already showing some frustration that I was not ready to be put on the floor and start providing them with support.  The position requires in-depth training, so stick to your guns.

review_title: Great people to work with, just not a fun environment
pros:
People are generally kind and caring
Doing your part to save lives, it's nice to know at the end of the day your work is going to help someone live, not just make a couple bucks
Small organization allows you to make an impact quickly if you work hard
cons:
Bonuses and raises aren't competitive rarely match adjust living rates
Little chance to move upward
Older style management techniques: Work hard. Annual reviews don't affect salary changes or bonuses, nor are they consistent across departments.
Support staff are neglected

job_title: Surgical Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: A really neat and unique position. You get to travel and meet some very cool people. This organization allows its surgical coordinators to do things that other OPOs I worked do not. A lot of freedom as long as you do your job.
cons: Management. The managers have no clue what the surgical coordinators really do. The implement  new protocols that do not make sense. I witnessed serval good employees leave due to poor management. Not all of the managers are in the wrong positions but most seem to be in the positions for reasons other than ability and knowledge.

job_title: Surgical Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: The team is great, experience is awesome, you get to save lives, learn on the job things you can never learn somewhere else about the human body. School doesn't come CLOSE to the stuff you learn here.
cons: management is messy. They honestly don't know what they are doing. They work you to the bone and expect you to never make mistakes when you haven't slept in 2 days.

job_title: Tissue Donation Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: Our tissue team is amazing! We have a very good working relationship with each other.  The shifts are 3 days one week and 4 days the next week for 12 hour shifts.  We have a great mission and get to save lives.  Also, management is so helpful and it's a positive work environment.
cons: Some families can be a handful and there's a lot of pressure to do things quickly.

review_title: In the non-profit world, the California Transplant Donor Network offers a lot of opportunities.
pros: Mission-driven organization and culture. Most employees believe in the cause.
cons: Most employees are spread out around the state working remotely and at variable hours. This can sometimes make it difficult to meet or work in teams.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Generous PTO Bank; casual corporate work environment at corporate with perks if you work in the office - otherwise you're out of luck.
cons: On call 24/7 and non-existent work-life balance; ever changing expectations; lack of camaraderie and open hostility among peer groups. Disregard for end of life experience as it becomes about production and numbers. Casual corporate work environment not translated to field. No management follow through even on serious issues.

job_title: Surgical Coordinator in San Ramon, CA
pros: Pay was great for my age and experience level
cons: Prepare to spend multiple days away from home during busy times, not a job for someone with a family, team is extremely close and clique-y, a lot of condescension, gossip, and unprofessional behavior being that there's hardly any oversight by management

pros: Donor Network West is a wonderful organization! Managment is very supportive, helpful and approachable. Encourage teamwork, bonding and management are always open to new ideas. Happy and relaxed atmosphere. They really care about their employees.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about Donor Network West.

cons: Organ and tissue donation is very rewarding but challenging work.   Workers in this industry can suffer compassion fatigue  and sometimes burnout.

pros: Very committed to the mission

pros: Friendly coworkers and environment , mostly decent pay

pros: The company has a great mission (saving and improving life's).

The epitome of micro-management.
Very over-bearing, controlling, and suffocating.
